Abandoned
Shouldn't we be returning an error here?

Ed
I don't think so, just do nothing while user patching of static ip addresses when DHCP enabled.

> Ed
> I don't think so, just do nothing while user patching of static ip addresses when DHCP enabled.

No...... why would we do nothing if the input parameters are incorrect?  Shouldn't we be informing the user that their input params are incorrect for the mode they're in?
Client should not assume that the setting is accepted by the BMC. Ravi, you may consider returning the error PropertyValueConflict - to give a meaningful response to the client.
done

The first issue makes sense. 
The 2nd one, I am struggling with but it arguably is no worse... I am struggling to see how another company would share this code but I think that is a broader discussion / beyond this commit.
yes, we can't delete, this commit fixes that behaviour
Why can you explain more?
Why is the DHCP address in the IPv4StaticAddresses to begin with if it can't be deleted?

DHCP address is not in  IPv4StaticAddresses, but when we try to patch  IPv4StaticAddresses with null, its deleting DHCP address which is not correct.
this commit corrects this behaviour by not allowing IPv4StaticAddresses patch while DHCP enabled.(as discussed we support only one IP on this hypervisor interface)

Gunnar

Do you still have question on this?
this commit waiting since long

> this commit waiting since long

But I came in and looked and you had not replied to all comments.

Ravi,

+1 on gunnars comment;  You haven't replied to the concerns.  Also this commit doesn't format its commit message 50/72, which implies that the author hasn't spent a lot of effort on it.  Maybe that's not the case, but reading and understanding what it takes to get code on master will help you in the long run.
sure. thank you. I will follow this

isn't this the same as below, this one is with DHCP disabled? and the 2nd one with DHCP enabled?

Something like would be more clear:
 
With DHCP disabled: 
curl -k -v -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "X-Auth-Token: $bmc_token" -X PATCH -d '{"IPv4StaticAddresses": [null]}' https://${bmc_ip}/redfish/v1/Systems/hypervisor/EthernetInterfaces/eth0
...
<insert http response codes>
...

With DHCP enabled: 
 curl -k -D headers.txt -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "X-Auth-Token: $bmc_token" -X PATCH -d '{"IPv4StaticAddresses": [null]}' https://${bmc_ip}/redfish/v1/Systems/hypervisor/EthernetInterfaces/eth0
{
  "error": {
    "@Message.ExtendedInfo": [
yes.that's correct.
Can you make more clear?

Gunnar 

as discussed earlier, we have only one ip configured for hypervisor.

as soon as DHCP enabled DHCP ip overrides static ip.
so in this case, we return error when user tries to delete static Ip when DHCP enabled. Ed and Sunitha agreed on same.

> only one ip configured for hypervisor

This feels like we are driving business logic into this Redfish interface.

This just doesn't feel super correct.
Wrap your commits 50/72 please.  This line looks like it's wrapped by hand at 50?  There are many lines that need fixed.

I think something like would be more clear

With DHCP disabled: 
curl -k -v -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "X-Auth-Token: $bmc_token" -X PATCH -d '{"IPv4StaticAddresses": [null]}' https://${bmc_ip}/redfish/v1/Systems/hypervisor/EthernetInterfaces/eth0
...
<insert http response codes>
...

With DHCP enabled: 
 curl -k -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "X-Auth-Token: $bmc_token" -X PATCH -d '{"IPv4StaticAddresses": [null]}' https://${bmc_ip}/redfish/v1/Systems/hypervisor/EthernetInterfaces/eth0
{
  "error": {
    "@Message.ExtendedInfo": [
This should be taken by value.
Done
I don't see this done.

> I don't see this done.

done
Why do we mention PLDM here at all?  This could be implemented by any subsystem (I understand it's pldm on your system).
Done

This seems wrong.  on all patches we're disabling the interface?  I feel like I'm missing something PATCH this patchset.  if the hypervisor daemon can't consume the updated settings, that sounds like an issue with it, not with our use here.

basically we wanted to display only ip config that's consumed by hypervisor.
if hypervisor consume IP config, then host interface gets a ack and host interface updates
this Enabled property to true.
If hypervisor can't consume, this property set to false and then we don't show any IP on GET

> basically we wanted to display only ip config that's consumed by hypervisor.

That's not how a REST api works.  If the PATCH is accepted, the tree should immediately change.

> if hypervisor consume IP config, then host interface gets a ack and host interface updates
> this Enabled property to true.

> If hypervisor can't consume, this property set to false and then we don't show any IP on GET


If the hypervisor can't consume the config, it should reject the attempt to set the parameter.  We should not be explicitly disabling the interface at a dbus level.
This looks fine.  Ideally this would've been put in another commit, but oh well, I guess we'll discuss the other change first.

> This looks fine.  Ideally this would've been put in another commit, but oh well, I guess we'll discuss the other change first.

ok, added  new commit https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/45626
If this check fails, we shouldn't be causing a propertyValueConflict error, this should be something about the propertyy not being allowed.

I think it's  already discussed, we thought propertyValueConflict makes more sense.

ok. I could not find property not allowed error defined

> I think it's  already discussed, we thought propertyValueConflict makes more sense.



> 
> ok. I could not find property not allowed error defined

Ah, i missed initially that this was checking the interlock between the two properties.  Ok, this makes sense.
Why the setIPv4InterfaceEnabled call is removed from here?

say if we tried to patch invalid ip details, handleHypervisorIPv4StaticPatch() method returns error for invalid ip details, but still this method call sets interface state to false.
which disables existing IP

so I moved this function call inside handleHypervisorIPv4StaticPatch()
Ack

This is still incorrect.  We should not be implicitly disabling an enthernet interface when the user hasn't explicitly requested it.  If this is needed on a network config change, then the daemon implementing the hypervisor network interface needs to be in charge of disabling/enabling the interface as needed.

Ed
I agree with you, but this is as per current design.
as you suggested we are coming up with new hypervisor network dbus app
we will address this comment as part new D-bus app
below commit has new D-bus app implementation
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-networkd/+/43173
once that's done I will remove this call.
Thanks

Yes. This call is needed as per the current backend design. 
Ed, the backend changes and the corresponding bmcweb changes will take considerable time in getting review-rework done. So is this commit good to go in now to fix the bug in hand ?

This feels wrong to me "implicitly disabling an enthernet interface when the user hasn't explicitly requested it". Can we just move forward with the changes lines 950 - 958 ? Can we address this when we do get the backend changes in?

> This feels wrong to me "implicitly disabling an enthernet interface when the user hasn't explicitly requested it". Can we just move forward with the changes lines 950 - 958 ? Can we address this when we do get the backend changes in?

If those changes are in a separate patchset, sure, that would be fine with me.

> Yes. This call is needed as per the current backend design. 

Cool.  Lets get that fixed before we try to tackle any of the other non-trivial issues, as I suspect that changing this will involve modifying some code behavior, and there's no point in doing the work twice.

I'm happy to field trivial changes on return codes and things ahead of time, but because the enable/disable flow isn't really matching the intent of the dbus interface, it's hard to verify the correctness of this patch as a maintainer until that's fixed.

Ack

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/45063 is the commit for the backend design change

The backend changes are couple of commits on phosphor-networkd starting from https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-networkd/+/43173

Please review them as provide your feedbacks, so that we can get a move on those commits soon.
